message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of pain, swelling, erythema, and dilated superficial veins suggests deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Venous duplex ultrasound confirms non-compressibility, which is indicative of DVT. Impaired venous blood flow is therefore the mechanism behind this patient’s illness. Impaired lymphatic blood flow can result in lymphedema, which typically presents with pitting edema and is not associated with erythema or dilated superficial veins. Subcutaneous soft-tissue infection and infection of dermis and subcutaneous tissues are also possible causes of leg swelling but would present with warmth and tenderness, and may have associated fever, which is not seen in this patient’s case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest deep vein thrombosis, which is caused by impaired venous blood flow. The increased calf circumference and erythema also points towards this diagnosis. Impaired lymphatic flow would cause swelling that is more diffuse and not localized to one leg. Soft-tissue infections and dermis/subcutaneous tissue infections would have different symptoms such as fever and pain on palpation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest deep vein thrombosis, which results in impaired venous blood flow. Impaired lymphatic flow is not a likely cause of the unilateral leg swelling. Subcutaneous soft-tissue infection and infection of the dermis and subcutaneous tissues would likely present with more significant signs of infection such as fever and systemic symptoms, which are not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and risk factors suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which impairs venous blood flow. The dilated superficial veins are a result of increased venous pressure. The other options do not explain the characteristic symptoms of DVT, such as unilateral leg swelling and erythema, and non-compressibility on ultrasound.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of recent air travel, diabetes, and smoking, along with the symptoms of pain, swelling, erythema, and dilated superficial veins, suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Venous duplex ultrasound supports the diagnosis of non-compressibility, which occurs due to impaired venous blood flow. None of the other options provide a plausible explanation for the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and risk factors suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which impairs venous blood flow. Non-compressibility found on venous duplex ultrasound confirms DVT. Options B, C, and D are all related to infections and are not the best choices for this patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and recent travel history suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is caused by impaired venous blood flow. Impaired lymphatic blood flow would not cause the marked edema seen in this patient. Subcutaneous soft-tissue infection and infection of the dermis and subcutaneous tissues would have additional signs of infection, such as warmth and tenderness, which are absent in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which impairs venous blood flow. The erythema, dilated superficial veins, and non-compressibility on ultrasound support this diagnosis. Impaired lymphatic flow would present with different symptoms, and soft-tissue infections would not show non-compressibility on ultrasound.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms and risk factors that suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which impairs venous blood flow. The dilated superficial veins and non-compressibility on venous duplex ultrasound confirm the diagnosis. The other options do not fit the presentation of the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is caused by impaired venous blood flow. B and C are unlikely given the clinical presentation and D is incorrect as there is no mention of an infection.
